title: Guided Transfer Learning for Discrete Diffusion Models
summary: This paper introduces Guided Transfer Learning (GTL) for discrete diffusion models, enabling adaptation to new target distributions without fine-tuning large pretrained denoisers. GTL provides a unified framework for both discrete-time and continuous-time discrete diffusion, further enhanced by an efficient sampler that significantly reduces computational cost for practical large-scale language modeling. This approach addresses the challenge of high training costs and data scarcity for specialized domains by making transfer learning more efficient.

title: Script Gap: Evaluating LLM Triage on Indian Languages in Native vs Roman Scripts in a Real World Setting
summary: This paper evaluates the performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) in maternal and newborn healthcare triage when processing Indian languages, specifically comparing native scripts to romanized text. It reveals a consistent and significant degradation in LLM performance (5-12 F1 points lower) for romanized inputs, which could lead to millions of excess triage errors in real-world clinical settings. Crucially, the study finds that LLMs often correctly infer the semantic intent of romanized queries but fail to reliably act on it in final classification due to orthographic noise.

title: Blood Pressure Prediction for Coronary Artery Disease Diagnosis using Coronary Computed Tomography Angiography
summary: This paper introduces an end-to-end pipeline that automates coronary geometry extraction from CCTA and streamlines the generation of simulated hemodynamic data. It then develops a diffusion-based regression model to predict coronary blood pressure directly from CCTA-derived features, bypassing computationally expensive CFD simulations. The model achieved state-of-the-art performance on a simulated dataset, offering a rapid and non-invasive approach for coronary artery disease diagnosis.

title: Modality-Specific Enhancement and Complementary Fusion for Semi-Supervised Multi-Modal Brain Tumor Segmentation
summary: This paper introduces a novel semi-supervised multi-modal framework designed to enhance brain tumor segmentation by effectively leveraging complementary information across different MRI sequences. It addresses limitations in existing methods by proposing a Modality-specific Enhancing Module (MEM) and a Complementary Information Fusion (CIF) module. The framework significantly outperforms strong baselines on the BraTS 2019 dataset, especially under very limited labeled data conditions, demonstrating improved Dice and Sensitivity scores.

title: Predicting Polymer Solubility in Solvents Using SMILES Strings
summary: This paper introduces a deep learning framework for predicting polymer solubility (weight percent) in various solvents directly from their SMILES representations. The model, a six-hidden-layer neural network, was trained on a large dataset of 8,049 simulated polymer-solvent pairs and achieved strong agreement with actual solubility, demonstrating generalizability on unseen experimental data. This approach enables scalable and high-throughput solvent screening for diverse applications, including green chemistry and materials design.

title: PathCo-LatticE: Pathology-Constrained Lattice-Of Experts Framework for Fully-supervised Few-Shot Cardiac MRI Segmentation
summary: PathCo-LatticE introduces a fully supervised few-shot learning (FSL) framework for cardiac MRI segmentation that overcomes data scarcity by generating pathology-guided synthetic data. It achieves robust zero-shot generalization to unseen data and pathologies by training specialized experts and validating without real data, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art methods in out-of-distribution settings.
